content:
Hyndburn Leisure Trust has reportedly lost money every year since its formation, costing taxpayers approximately £1 million per year in council subsidies. Now the trust is requesting a further £12 million capital investment for a new facility at Wilson's Playing Field. The cumulative cost to Hyndburn residents raises serious questions about whether the trust model is delivering value for money.

The Annual Subsidy

When councils transfer leisure services to an independent trust, the stated rationale is typically to achieve savings — particularly through business rates relief that trusts can access as charitable bodies. In Hyndburn's case, this model appears to have done the opposite.

The trust has reportedly required approximately £1 million per year in revenue subsidy from Hyndburn Borough Council to cover its operating losses. This is money that comes directly from the council's general fund — the same pot that pays for waste collection, planning services, environmental health, and all other council functions.

Cumulative Cost to Taxpayers

Cost Category Estimated Amount
Annual revenue subsidy (approx. per year)£1,000,000
Cumulative subsidy over trust lifetime (estimated 10+ years)£10,000,000+
Proposed Wilson's Playing Field capital investment£12,000,000
Estimated total cost to taxpayers£22,000,000+

At over £22 million and counting, the total exposure of Hyndburn taxpayers to the leisure trust model is substantial — particularly for a small district council with a net revenue budget of approximately £12 million per year.

The Parkinson Legacy: A Decade of Subsidised Losses

The leisure trust model was championed and maintained throughout the 12-year leadership of Cllr Miles Parkinson (2011-2023). During his entire tenure as Leader, the trust reportedly never turned a profit — yet Parkinson continued to authorise the annual subsidy year after year without publicly questioning whether the model was working.

More significantly, it was under Parkinson's leadership that the council began pursuing the £12 million Wilson's Playing Field investment, securing £2.4 million from Sport England and committing significant council resources to the project. Parkinson personally championed the "Hyndburn Leisure Transformation" programme, presenting it as a major achievement — yet the fundamental question was never publicly addressed: why should taxpayers invest £12 million more in a trust that has never operated at a surplus?

Parkinson's centralised decision-making style meant that scrutiny of the leisure trust's finances was limited. With one person dominating council decisions for over a decade, the checks and balances that might have forced a rethink of the trust model were weakened. By the time Parkinson lost his seat in May 2023, Hyndburn taxpayers were already committed to a project built on a foundation of perpetual losses.

The £12 Million Capital Ask

The trust has reportedly requested £12 million in capital funding from the council for a new facility at Wilson's Playing Field. For context:

  • £12 million is roughly equivalent to Hyndburn's entire annual net revenue budget
  • The council would likely need to borrow this sum, incurring interest costs for decades
  • Annual loan repayments on £12 million could exceed £600,000 per year for 25 years
  • This would be on top of the existing ~£1 million annual subsidy

If approved, Hyndburn taxpayers could be paying £1.6 million per year — nearly one-eighth of the council's entire net budget — to support a leisure trust that has never operated at a surplus.

How Pendle Manages Leisure Services

Neighbouring Pendle Borough Council takes a different approach to leisure provision. Rather than operating through an arms-length trust that requires ongoing subsidy, Pendle has pursued a model that places greater emphasis on financial sustainability and direct accountability to elected members.

The key differences are instructive:

  • Direct accountability: When leisure is managed in-house or through tighter contractual arrangements, councillors have greater oversight of spending decisions
  • Financial discipline: Services that sit within the council's own budget are subject to the same scrutiny as other departments
  • Transparency: Spending on leisure appears directly in council accounts rather than being channelled through a separate body

The Trust Model: Who Benefits?

The leisure trust model was widely promoted in the 2000s and 2010s as a way for councils to save money on business rates while maintaining service delivery. However, the Hyndburn experience raises questions about who actually benefits:

Stakeholder Outcome
Trust board membersOversight of significant public assets with limited public scrutiny
Trust managementSalaries funded by public subsidy, outside council pay scales
Council membersReduced direct control over leisure services and spending
Hyndburn taxpayers£1M per year in subsidies, now asked for £12M more

Questions the Council Should Answer

  1. What is the total cumulative subsidy paid to Hyndburn Leisure Trust since formation?
  2. Has the trust ever operated at a surplus in any financial year?
  3. What business case supports the £12 million Wilson's Playing Field investment?
  4. What alternative delivery models have been considered, and at what cost?
  5. How do trust board members' remuneration packages compare to equivalent council roles?
  6. What performance targets is the trust required to meet, and has it met them?

Until these questions are answered transparently, residents should scrutinise any further capital commitments to the trust with extreme care. A model that has cost over £10 million in subsidies without ever turning a profit deserves rigorous challenge before being given £12 million more.

Financial estimates based on publicly reported figures and council budget documents. Exact cumulative subsidy figures should be confirmed by the council through a Freedom of Information request.
